items.content_html:
Part of #9842.

This PR is all about tables. Specifically, it includes:

  • an analysis of how table conversion went in /Mozilla/Add-ons
  • a few fixes to make some tables convertible

The background is that the Markdown syntax for tables is pretty limited (https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/MDN/Contribute/Markdown_in_MDN#tables), and many of MDN's tables are not convertible to Markdown. So our policy here is basically: convert tables to Markdown when we can, and use HTML otherwise.

In /Mozilla/Add-ons, we have 77 tables, and zero of them get converted to Markdown. I've checked through all of these, and:

  • Most of these tables are in the manifest.json section (e.g. https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Add-ons/WebExtensions/manifest.json/author) and these tables are inherently non-convertible.
  • Most of the rest are also unconvertible for legit reasons (they have header columns, they contain block elements, they are too wide, ...)

There are a few that would be convertible with a little tweaking,and that's what this PR contains.

We might decide that, given that so few tables are convertible in this section of the docs, it would be better to keep all tables as HTML, and in that case we should just close this PR.
items.title: [Markdown][Add-ons] Deal with tables

items.content_html:
Summary

Fixes for #9456 to make the format of DOM Exceptions consistent.

Updated the following files:

    • files/en-us/web/api/xrsession/requestlightprobe/index.md
    • files/en-us/web/api/xrsession/updaterenderstate/index.md
    • files/en-us/web/api/mediarecorder/pause/index.md (plus removed contractions like 'can't' and 'it's' and replaced pronouns)
    • files/en-us/web/api/mediarecorder/start/index.md (plus minor edits)
    • files/en-us/web/api/audioencoder/encode/index.md
    • files/en-us/web/api/audioencoder/flush/index.md (plus minor edit)
    • files/en-us/web/api/xrwebglbinding/xrwebglbinding/index.md
    • files/en-us/web/api/idbdatabase/transaction/index.md (minor typo fix, it was already in the required format)
    • files/en-us/web/api/idbdatabase/createobjectstore/index.md (plus minor edits)
      I have converted the Exceptions table to list. In the 'InvalidStateError', there is a link: {{APIRef("IDBVersionChangeRequest.setVersion")}}. However, the page https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/IDBVersionChangeRequest does not exist. How does this need to be fixed?

Questions

  • files/en-us/web/api/mediarecorder/onerror/index.md
    Should the 'Value' section be changed to 'Exceptions' and the errors listed be formatted as DOM Exceptions?
  • files/en-us/web/api/paymentrequest/show/index.md
    In the 'Exceptions' section, should 'Returned' (for all exception descriptions) be updated to 'Thrown' to maintain consistency?
  • files/en-us/web/api/idbrequest/index.md
    There is no 'Exceptions' section here. Are there any other changes required?
  • files/en-us/web/api/idbrequest/error/index.md
    There is no 'Exceptions' section here. Should the 'Value' section be changed to 'Exceptions', the table updated to list, and the errors be formatted as DOM Exceptions?
  • files/en-us/web/api/idbrequest/result/index.md
    There is no Exceptions section here. Are there any other changes required?

Ok As Is

DOM Exceptions in the following files are already in the required format:

  • files/en-us/web/api/audioencoder/configure/index.md
  • files/en-us/web/api/xrwebglbinding/getdepthinformation/index.md
  • files/en-us/web/api/idbdatabase/deleteobjectstore/index.md
items.title: Updated format for DOM Exceptions

Summary

Remove PR title linting GitHub Actions workflow and code.

Motivation

This came up during the Write the Docs Prague 2021 Writing Day. It's mostly just a hassle for maintainers and an unwelcoming introduction to the project for new contributors. I don't know if there are better ways to do this, but this is not a good one.

Supporting details

See #9483 for additional description and gripes.

Related issues

Fixes #9483

items.content_html:
Part of #9842.

The "Chrome incompatibilities" page (https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Add-ons/WebExtensions/Chrome_incompatibilities) contained some <dl> elements which would not be convertible into our Markdown <dl>. It would have been possible to hack them so they would be convertible, but I thought this page was quite difficult to understand so I have had a go at reworking the markup at the same time.

I hope you think it is at least not any worse!

items.content_html:
Summary

Add page for Array_withSorted_argument type error message

Motivation

Bug 1729563 adds a new Array.prototype.withSorted() method. This method can throw a type error that is similar to the one thrown by Array.prototype.sort() when the function argument is not callable, but the name is different to reflect that the method being erroneously called is withSorted().

Supporting details

items.title: [DOM Reference] Update CustomEvent interface reference

items.content_html:
sendResponse() is deprecated

Summary

The sendResponse() function is deprecated and should no longer be used. This PR changes the used examples to return a Promise and shows the two possible ways to do it.

I removed usage of sendResponse() in the example and let the handler return a Promise. Once as being an async function and always returning a Promise, which is fine if only one such listener is registered, which is 99% use-case out there, but also pointing out how to do it if multiple listeners are used.

Motivation

I am the lead add-on reviewer for Thunderbird and I get sendResponse() in reviews a lot and developers pointed me to this page showing them the deprecated usage.

Metadata

  • Adds a new document
  • Rewrites (or significantly expands) a document
  • Fixes a typo, bug, or other error
items.title: Adding a note about the option to return a Promise instead of using the sendResponse() function

items.content_html:
Part of #9842.

This fixes almost all the <dl> elements in the add-ons docs so that they can be represented with our Markdown <dl>.

One big piece of this is that our Markdown <dl> doesn't let you have consecutive <dd> elements. Although that is allowed in the HTML <dd>, when we have consecutive <dd> in MDN it is (almost?) always an error (a legacy of the old WYSIWYG editor). This PR aims to fix all of these in the add-ons docs.

This PR also includes fixes for other things inside <dl> elements, notably some difficulty that the converter has in converting <dd> elements that don't start with a paragraph or text node. Although this is technically a bug in the converter (mdn/yari#4307) in practice it either shows us a place where we are not using <dl> properly, or where the content would be improved by having some text at the start of the <dd> element (see also #7309).

One thing I have excluded from this PR is https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Add-ons/WebExtensions/Chrome_incompatibilities, which makes very extensive and (IMO) sometimes questionable (semantically) use of <dl>. I will file a separate PR for this since it might warrant its own discussion.
items.title: [Markdown][Add-ons] Fix <dl> elements

items.content_html:
This is part of the action to remove page macros in #3196

The CSS @media was importing the media types and media features section from using media queries.

This copies the text across instead. The big table of media types is converted to a definition list, which is more in line with other reference docs.

@wbamberg I hate the duplication here because they really must always be the same for this case ... but anyhow. Do you think I should update the table in "Using" docs to match the new definition list format? If I did this I would probably mark the info about spec version things came in as in italic.
items.title: PageMacro: Remove from CSS @media
